TEXT: Chapter 1 [PETER]_n0 BREAKS THROUGH All children, except one, grow up. [They]_p0 soon know that [they]_p1 will grow up, and the way [Wendy]_n1 knew was this. [One]_n2 day when [she]_p2 was two years old [she]_p3 was playing in a garden, and [she]_p3 plucked another flower and ran with [it]_p5 to [her]_p6 mother. [I]_p7 suppose [she]_p8 must have looked rather delightful, for [Mrs Darling]_n3 put [her]_p9 hand to [her]_p10 heart and cried,. "Oh, why can't [you]_p11 remain like this for ever!". This was all that passed between [them]_p12 on the subject, but henceforth [Wendy]_n4 knew that [she]_p13 must grow up. [You]_p14 always know after [you]_p15 are two. Two is the beginning of the end. Of course [they]_p16 lived at 14 [their house number on [their]_p17 street], and until [Wendy]_n5 came [her]_p19 mother was the chief one. [She]_p20 was a lovely [lady]_n6 , with a romantic mind and such a sweet mocking mouth.

[Her]_p21 romantic mind was like the tiny boxes, one within the other, that come from the puzzling [East]_n7 , however many [you]_p22 discover there is always one more and [her]_p23 sweet mocking mouth had one kiss on [it]_p24 that [Wendy]_n8 could never get, though there [it]_p25 was, perfectly conspicuous in the right-hand corner. The way [Mr Darling]_n9 won [her]_p26 was this: the many gentlemen who had been boys when [she]_p31 was a girl discovered simultaneously that [they]_p32 loved her, and [they]_p33 all ran to [her]_p27 house to propose to [her]_p27 except [Mr Darling]_n10 , who took a cab and nipped in first, and so [he]_p34 got her. [He]_p35 got all of her, except the innermost box and the kiss. [He]_p36 never knew about the box, and in time [he]_p37 gave up trying for the kiss. [Wendy]_n11 thought [Napoleon]_n12 could have got it, but [I]_p38 can picture [him]_p39 trying, and then going off in a passion, slamming the door. [Mr Darling]_n13 used to boast to [Wendy]_n14 that [her]_p40 mother not only loved [him]_p41 but respected him. [He]_p43 was one of those deep ones who know about stocks and shares. Of course no one really knows, but [he]_p44 quite seemed to know, and [he]_p45 often said stocks were up and shares were down in a way that would have made any woman respect him. [Mrs Darling]_n15 was married in white, and at first [she]_p46 kept the books perfectly, almost gleefully, as if [it]_p47 were a game, not so much as a [Brussels]_n16 sprout was missing but by and by whole cauliflowers dropped out, and instead of [them]_p48 there were pictures of babies without faces. [She]_p49 drew [them]_p50 when [she]_p51 should have been totting up.

[They]_p52 were [Mrs Darling]_n17 's guesses. [Wendy]_n18 came first, then [John]_n19 , then [Michael]_n20. For a week or two after [Wendy]_n21 came [it]_p53 was doubtful whether [they]_p54 would be able to keep her, as [she]_p55 was another mouth to feed. [Mr Darling]_n22 was frightfully proud of her, but [he]_p58 was very honourable, and [he]_p59 sat on the edge of [Mrs Darling]_n23 's bed, holding [her]_p56 hand and calculating expenses, while [she]_p60 looked at [him]_p61 imploringly. [She]_p62 wanted to risk it, come what might, but that was not [his]_p63 way [his]_p64 way was with a pencil and a piece of paper, and if [she]_p65 confused [him]_p66 with suggestions [he]_p67 had to begin at the beginning again. "Now don't interrupt,". [he]_p68 would beg of her. "[I]_p69 have one pound seventeen here, and two and six at the office [I]_p70 can cut off [my]_p73 coffee at the office, say ten shillings, making two nine and six, with [your]_p76 eighteen and three makes three nine seven, with five naught naught in [my]_p74 cheque-book makes eight nine seven, who is that moving?, eight nine seven, dot and carry seven, don't speak, [my]_p74 own, and the pound [you]_p77 lent to that man who came to the door, quiet, child, dot and carry child, there, you've done it!, did [I]_p70 say nine nine seven? yes, [I]_p71 said nine nine seven the question is, can [we]_p81 try [it]_p79 for a year on nine nine seven?. "Of course [we]_p82 can, [George]_n24 ,". [she]_p83 cried.

But [she]_p84 was prejudiced in [Wendy]_n25 's favour, and [he]_p85 was really the grander character of the two. "Remember mumps,". [he]_p86 warned [her]_p88 almost threateningly, and off [he]_p87 went again. "Mumps one pound, that is what [I]_p89 have put down, but [I]_p90 daresay [it]_p91 will be more like thirty shillings, don't speak, measles one five, German measles half a guinea, makes two fifteen six, don't waggle [your]_p94 finger, whooping-cough, say fifteen shillings , and so on [it]_p92 went, and [it]_p92 added up differently each time but at last [Wendy]_n26 just got through, with mumps reduced to twelve six, and the two kinds of measles treated as one. There was the same excitement over [John]_n27 , and [Michael]_n28 had even a narrower squeak but both were kept, and soon, [you]_p95 might have seen the three of [them]_p96 going in a row to [Miss Fulsom]_n29 's [Kindergarten]_n30 school, accompanied by [their]_p97 nurse. [Mrs Darling]_n31 loved to have everything just so, and [Mr Darling]_n32 had a passion for being exactly like [his]_p98 neighbours so, of course, [they]_p99 had a nurse. As [they]_p100 were poor, owing to the amount of milk the children drank, this nurse was a prim [Newfoundland]_n33 dog, called [Nana]_n34 , who had belonged to no one in particular until the Darlings engaged her. [She]_p101 had always thought children important, however, and the Darlings had become acquainted with [her]_p102 in [Kensington Gardens]_n35 , where [she]_p104 spent most of [her]_p103 spare time peeping into perambulators, and was much hated by careless nursemaids, whom [she]_p105 followed to [their]_p106 homes and complained of to [their]_p107 mistresses. [She]_p108 proved to be quite a treasure of a nurse. How thorough [she]_p109 was at bath-time, and up at any moment of the night if one of [her]_p110 charges made the slightest cry.

Of course [her]_p111 kennel was in the nursery. [She]_p112 had a genius for knowing when a cough is a thing to have no patience with and when [it]_p113 needs stocking around [your]_p114 throat. [She]_p115 believed to [her]_p116 last day in old-fashioned remedies like rhubarb leaf, and made sounds of contempt over all this new-fangled talk about germs, and so on. [It]_p117 was a lesson in propriety to see [her]_p118 escorting the children to school, walking sedately by [their]_p119 side when [they]_p120 were well behaved, and butting [them]_p122 back into line if [they]_p121 strayed. On [John]_n36 's footer [in [England]_n37 soccer was called football,. "footer". for short] days [she]_p123 never once forgot [his]_p125 sweater, and [she]_p124 usually carried an umbrella in [her]_p126 mouth in case of rain. There is a room in the basement of [Miss Fulsom]_n38 's school where the nurses wait. [They]_p127 sat on forms, while [Nana]_n39 lay on the floor, but that was the only difference. [They]_p128 affected to ignore [her]_p129 as of an inferior social status to themselves, and [she]_p130 despised [their]_p131 light talk.

[She]_p132 resented visits to the nursery from [Mrs Darling]_n40 's friends, but if [they]_p133 did come [she]_p134 first whipped off [Michael]_n41 's pinafore and put [him]_p135 into the one with blue braiding, and smoothed out [Wendy]_n42 and made a dash at [John]_n43 's hair. No nursery could possibly have been conducted more correctly, and [Mr Darling]_n44 knew it, yet [he]_p136 sometimes wondered uneasily whether the neighbours talked. [He]_p137 had [his]_p138 position in the city to consider. [Nana]_n45 also troubled [him]_p139 in another way. [He]_p140 had sometimes a feeling that [she]_p141 did not admire him. "[I]_p142 know [she]_p143 admires [you]_p145 tremendously, [George]_n46 , Mrs Darling would assure him, and then [she]_p144 would sign to the children to be specially nice to father. Lovely dances followed, in which the only other servant, [Liza]_n47 , was sometimes allowed to join. Such a midget [she]_p146 looked in [her]_p149 long skirt and maid's cap, though [she]_p147 had sworn, when engaged, that [she]_p147 would never see ten again. The gaiety of those romps! And gayest of all was [Mrs Darling]_n48 , who would pirouette so wildly that all [you]_p150 could see of [her]_p153 was the kiss, and then if [you]_p151 had dashed at [her]_p154 [you]_p151 might have got it. There never was a simpler happier family until the coming of [Peter Pan]_n49.

[Mrs Darling]_n50 first heard of [Peter]_n51 when [she]_p155 was tidying up [her]_p156 children's minds. [It]_p157 is the nightly custom of every good mother after [her]_p158 children are [asleep]_n52 to rummage in [their]_p159 minds and put things straight for next morning, repacking into [their]_p160 proper places the many articles that have wandered during the day. If [you]_p161 could keep awake (but of course [you]_p162 can't) [you]_p162 would see [your]_p165 own mother doing this, and [you]_p163 would find [it]_p166 very interesting to watch her. [It]_p167 is quite like tidying up drawers. [You]_p168 would see [her]_p169 on [her]_p170 knees, [I]_p172 expect, lingering humorously over some of [your]_p173 contents, wondering where on earth [you]_p174 had picked this thing up, making discoveries sweet and not so sweet, pressing this to [her]_p170 cheek as if [it]_p175 were as nice as a kitten, and hurriedly stowing that out of sight. When [you]_p176 wake in the morning, the naughtiness and evil passions with which [you]_p177 went to bed have been folded up small and placed at the bottom of [your]_p179 mind and on the top, beautifully aired, are spread out [your]_p180 prettier thoughts, ready for [you]_p177 to put on. [I]_p181 don't know whether [you]_p182 have ever seen a map of a person's mind. Doctors sometimes draw maps of other parts of you, and [your]_p183 own map can become intensely interesting, but catch [them]_p184 trying to draw a map of a child's mind, which is not only confused, but keeps going round all the time. There are zigzag lines on it, just like [your]_p185 temperature on a card, and these are probably roads in the island, for the [Neverland]_n53 is always more or less an island, with astonishing splashes of colour here and there, and coral reefs and rakish-looking craft in the offing, and savages and lonely lairs, and gnomes who are mostly tailors, and caves through which a river runs, and princes with six elder brothers, and a hut fast going to decay, and one very small old [lady]_n54 with a hooked nose. [It]_p186 would be an easy map if that were all, but there is also first day at school, religion, fathers, the round pond, needle-work, murders, hangings, verbs that take the dative, chocolate pudding day, getting into braces, say ninety-nine, three-pence for pulling out [your]_p187 tooth yourself, and so on, and either these are part of the island or [they]_p188 are another map showing through, and [it]_p189 is all rather confusing, especially as nothing will stand still.

Of course the Neverlands vary a good deal. [John]_n55 's, for instance, had a lagoon with flamingoes flying over [it]_p190 at which [John]_n56 was shooting, while [Michael]_n57 , who was very small, had a flamingo with lagoons flying over it. [John]_n58 lived in a boat turned upside down on the sands, [Michael]_n59 in a wigwam, [Wendy]_n60 in a house of leaves deftly sewn together. John had no friends, [Michael]_n61 had friends at night, [Wendy]_n62 had a pet wolf forsaken by [its]_p192 parents, but on the whole the Neverlands have a family resemblance, and if [they]_p193 stood still in a row [you]_p195 could say of [them]_p196 that [they]_p194 have each other's nose, and so forth. On these magic shores children at play are for ever beaching [their]_p197 coracles [simple boat]. [We]_p198 too have been there [we]_p199 can still hear the sound of the surf, though [we]_p200 shall land no more. Of all delectable islands the [Neverland]_n63 is the snuggest and most compact, not large and sprawly, [you]_p201 know, with tedious distances between one adventure and another, but nicely crammed. When [you]_p202 play at [it]_p204 by day with the chairs and table-cloth, [it]_p205 is not in the least alarming, but in the two minutes before [you]_p203 go to sleep [it]_p205 becomes very real. That is why there are night-lights. Occasionally in [her]_p207 travels through [her]_p208 children's minds [Mrs Darling]_n64 found things [she]_p209 could not understand, and of these quite the most perplexing was the word [Peter]_n65.

[She]_p210 knew of no [Peter]_n66 , and yet [he]_p211 was here and there in [John]_n67 and [Michael]_n68 's minds, while [Wendy]_n69 's began to be scrawled all over with him. The name stood out in bolder letters than any of the other words, and as [Mrs Darling]_n70 gazed [she]_p212 felt that [it]_p213 had an oddly cocky appearance. "Yes, [he]_p214 is rather cocky,". [Wendy]_n71 admitted with regret. [Her]_p215 mother had been questioning her. "But who is he, [my]_p216 pet?. "[He]_p217 is [Peter Pan]_n72 , [you]_p218 know, mother. At first [Mrs Darling]_n73 did not know, but after thinking back into [her]_p219 childhood [she]_p220 just remembered a [Peter Pan]_n74 who was said to live with the fairies. There were odd stories about him, as that when children died [he]_p221 went part of the way with them, so that [they]_p222 should not be frightened. [She]_p223 had believed in [him]_p224 at the time, but now that [she]_p225 was married and full of sense [she]_p226 quite doubted whether there was any such person.

"Besides,". [she]_p227 said to [Wendy]_n75 ,. "[he]_p228 would be grown up by this time. "Oh no, [he]_p229 isn't grown up,". [Wendy]_n76 assured [her]_p230 confidently,. "and [he]_p231 is just [my]_p232 size. ". [She]_p233 meant that [he]_p234 was [her]_p235 size in both mind and body [she]_p236 didn't know how [she]_p237 knew, [she]_p237 just knew it. [Mrs Darling]_n77 consulted [Mr Darling]_n78 , but [he]_p239 smiled pooh-pooh. "Mark [my]_p240 words,".

[he]_p241 said,. "[it]_p242 is some nonsense [Nana]_n79 has been putting into [their]_p243 heads just the sort of idea a dog would have. Leave [it]_p244 alone, and [it]_p245 will blow over. But [it]_p246 would not blow over and soon the troublesome boy gave [Mrs Darling]_n80 quite a shock. Children have the strangest adventures without being troubled by them. For instance, [they]_p247 may remember to mention, a week after the event happened, that when [they]_p248 were in the wood [they]_p248 had met [their]_p250 dead father and had a game with him. [It]_p251 was in this casual way that [Wendy]_n81 one morning made a disquieting revelation. Some leaves of a tree had been found on the nursery floor, which certainly were not there when the children went to bed, and [Mrs Darling]_n82 was puzzling over [them]_p252 when [Wendy]_n83 said with a tolerant smile:. "[I]_p253 do believe [it]_p254 is that [Peter]_n84 again!. "Whatever do [you]_p255 mean, [Wendy]_n85 ?.

"[It]_p256 is so naughty of [him]_p257 not to wipe [his]_p258 feet,". [Wendy]_n86 said, sighing. [She]_p259 was a tidy child. [She]_p260 explained in quite a matter-of-fact way that [she]_p261 thought [Peter]_n87 sometimes came to the nursery in the night and sat on the foot of [her]_p262 bed and played on [his]_p264 pipes to her. Unfortunately [she]_p265 never woke, so [she]_p266 didn't know how [she]_p266 knew, [she]_p267 just knew. "What nonsense [you]_p269 talk, precious. No one can get into the house without knocking. "[I]_p270 think [he]_p271 comes in by the window,". [she]_p272 said. "[My]_p273 love, [it]_p274 is three floors up.

"Were not the leaves at the foot of the window, mother?   [It]_p275 was quite true the leaves had been found very near the window. [Mrs Darling]_n88 did not know what to think, for [it]_p276 all seemed so natural to [Wendy]_n89 that [you]_p278 could not dismiss [it]_p277 by saying [she]_p279 had been dreaming. "[My]_p280 child,". the mother cried,. "why did [you]_p281 not tell [me]_p282 of this before?. "[I]_p283 forgot,". said [Wendy]_n90 lightly. [She]_p284 was in a hurry to get [her]_p285 breakfast. Oh, surely [she]_p286 must have been dreaming. But, on the other hand, there were the leaves.

[Mrs Darling]_n91 examined [them]_p287 very carefully [they]_p288 were skeleton leaves, but [she]_p290 was sure [they]_p289 did not come from any tree that grew in [England]_n92. [She]_p291 crawled about the floor, peering at [it]_p292 with a candle for marks of a strange foot. [She]_p293 rattled the poker up the chimney and tapped the walls. [She]_p294 let down a tape from the window to the pavement, and [it]_p295 was a sheer drop of thirty feet, without so much as a spout to climb up by. Certainly [Wendy]_n93 had been dreaming. But [Wendy]_n94 had not been dreaming, as the very next night showed, the night on which the extraordinary adventures of these children may be said to have begun. On the night [we]_p296 speak of all the children were once more in bed. [It]_p297 happened to be [Nana]_n95 's evening off, and [Mrs Darling]_n96 had bathed [them]_p298 and sung to [them]_p299 till one by one [they]_p300 had let go [her]_p301 hand and slid away into the land of sleep. All were looking so safe and cosy that [she]_p302 smiled at [her]_p303 fears now and sat down tranquilly by the fire to sew. [It]_p304 was something for [Michael]_n97 , who on [his]_p305 birthday was getting into shirts.

The fire was warm, however, and the nursery dimly lit by three night-lights, and presently the sewing lay on [Mrs Darling]_n98 's lap. Then [her]_p306 head nodded, oh, so gracefully. [She]_p307 was [asleep]_n99. Look at the four of them, [Wendy]_n100 and [Michael]_n101 over there, [John]_n102 here, and [Mrs Darling]_n103 by the fire. There should have been a fourth night-light. While [she]_p308 slept [she]_p309 had a dream. [She]_p310 dreamt that the [Neverland]_n104 had come too near and that a strange boy had broken through from it. [He]_p311 did not alarm her, for [she]_p312 thought [she]_p313 had seen [him]_p314 before in the faces of many women who have no children. Perhaps [he]_p315 is to be found in the faces of some mothers also. But in [her]_p316 dream [he]_p317 had rent the film that obscures the [Neverland]_n105 , and [she]_p318 saw [Wendy]_n106 and [John]_n107 and [Michael]_n108 peeping through the gap.

The dream by [itself]_p319 would have been a trifle, but while [she]_p320 was dreaming the window of the nursery blew open, and a boy did drop on the floor. [He]_p321 was accompanied by a strange light, no bigger than [your]_p322 fist, which darted about the room like a living thing and [I]_p323 think [it]_p324 must have been this light that wakened [Mrs Darling]_n109. [She]_p325 started up with a cry, and saw the boy, and somehow [she]_p326 knew at once that [he]_p327 was [Peter Pan]_n110. If [you]_p328 or [I]_p329 or [Wendy]_n111 had been there [we]_p330 should have seen that [he]_p331 was very like [Mrs Darling]_n112 's kiss. [He]_p332 was a lovely boy, clad in skeleton leaves and the juices that ooze out of trees but the most entrancing thing about [him]_p333 was that [he]_p334 had all [his]_p335 first teeth. When [he]_p336 saw [she]_p338 was a grown-up, [he]_p337 gnashed the little pearls at her. Chapter 2 THE SHADOW [Mrs Darling]_n113 screamed, and, as if in answer to a bell, the door opened, and [Nana]_n114 entered, returned from [her]_p339 evening out. [She]_p340 growled and sprang at the boy, who leapt lightly through the window. Again [Mrs Darling]_n115 screamed, this time in distress for him, for [she]_p341 thought [he]_p346 was killed, and [she]_p342 ran down into the street to look for [his]_p347 little body, but [it]_p348 was not there and [she]_p342 looked up, and in the black night [she]_p343 could see nothing but what [she]_p343 thought was a shooting star. [She]_p349 returned to the nursery, and found [Nana]_n116 with something in [her]_p350 mouth, which proved to be the boy's shadow.

As [he]_p351 leapt at the window [Nana]_n117 had closed [it]_p352 quickly, too late to catch him, but [his]_p354 shadow had not had time to get out slam went the window and snapped [it]_p353 off. [You]_p355 may be sure [Mrs Darling]_n118 examined the shadow carefully, but [it]_p356 was quite the ordinary kind. [Nana]_n119 had no doubt of what was the best thing to do with this shadow. [She]_p357 hung [it]_p358 out at the window, meaning. "[He]_p359 is sure to come back for [it]_p360 let [us]_p363 put [it]_p361 where [he]_p364 can get [it]_p361 easily without disturbing the children. But unfortunately [Mrs Darling]_n120 could not leave [it]_p365 hanging out at the window, [it]_p366 looked so like the washing and lowered the whole tone of the house. [She]_p367 thought of showing [it]_p368 to [Mr Darling]_n121 , but [he]_p370 was totting up winter great-coats for [John]_n122 and [Michael]_n123 , with a wet towel around [his]_p372 head to keep [his]_p373 brain clear, and [it]_p369 seemed a shame to trouble [him]_p374 besides, [she]_p375 knew exactly what [he]_p371 would say:. "[It]_p376 all comes of having a dog for a nurse. [She]_p377 decided to roll the shadow up and put [it]_p378 away carefully in a drawer, until a fitting opportunity came for telling [her]_p379 husband. Ah me! The opportunity came a week later, on that never-to-be-forgotten [Friday]_n124.

Of course [it]_p380 was a [Friday]_n125. "[I]_p381 ought to have been specially careful on a [Friday]_n126 ,". [she]_p382 used to say afterwards to [her]_p383 husband, while perhaps [Nana]_n127 was on the other side of her, holding [her]_p384 hand. "No, no,". [Mr Darling]_n128 always said,. "[I]_p386 am responsible for [it]_p387 all. I, [George Darling]_n129 , did it. [MEA CULPA]_n130 , [MEA CULPA]_n131. ". [He]_p388 had had a classical education.

[They]_p389 sat thus night after night recalling that fatal [Friday]_n132 , till every detail of [it]_p390 was stamped on [their]_p391 brains and came through on the other side like the faces on a bad coinage. "If only [I]_p392 had not accepted that invitation to dine at 27,". [Mrs Darling]_n133 said. "If only [I]_p393 had not poured [my]_p394 medicine into [Nana]_n134 's bowl,". said [Mr Darling]_n135. "If only [I]_p395 had pretended to like the medicine,". was what [Nana]_n136 's wet eyes said. "[My]_p396 liking for parties, [George]_n137. "[My]_p397 fatal gift of humour, dearest. "[My]_p398 touchiness about trifles, dear master and mistress.

Then one or more of [them]_p399 would break down altogether [Nana]_n138 at the thought,. "It's true, it's true, [they]_p400 ought not to have had a dog for a nurse. ". Many a time [it]_p401 was [Mr Darling]_n139 who put the handkerchief to [Nana]_n140 's eyes. "That fiend!". [Mr Darling]_n141 would cry, and [Nana]_n142 's bark was the echo of it, but [Mrs Darling]_n143 never upbraided [Peter]_n144 there was something in the right-hand corner of [her]_p402 mouth that wanted [her]_p403 not to call [Peter]_n145 names. [They]_p404 would sit there in the empty nursery, recalling fondly every smallest detail of that dreadful evening. [It]_p405 had begun so uneventfully, so precisely like a hundred other evenings, with [Nana]_n146 putting on the water for [Michael]_n147 's bath and carrying [him]_p406 to [it]_p407 on [her]_p408 back. "[I]_p409 won't go to bed,". [he]_p410 had shouted, like one who still believed that [he]_p411 had the last word on the subject,.

"[I]_p412 won't, [I]_p413 won't. [Nana]_n148 , [it]_p414 isn't six o'clock yet. Oh dear, oh dear, [I]_p415 shan't love [you]_p416 any more, [Nana]_n149. [I]_p417 tell [you]_p421 [I]_p418 won't be bathed, [I]_p418 won't, [I]_p419 won't! Then [Mrs Darling]_n150 had come in, wearing [her]_p422 white evening-gown. [She]_p423 had dressed early because [Wendy]_n151 so loved to see [her]_p424 in [her]_p425 evening-gown, with the necklace [George]_n152 had given her. [She]_p427 was wearing [Wendy]_n153 's bracelet on [her]_p428 arm [she]_p429 had asked for the loan of it. [Wendy]_n154 loved to lend [her]_p430 bracelet to [her]_p431 mother. [She]_p432 had found [her]_p433 two older children playing at being [herself]_p434 and father on the occasion of [Wendy]_n155 's birth, and [John]_n156 was saying:. "[I]_p435 am happy to inform you, [Mrs Darling]_n157 , that [you]_p436 are now a mother, in just such a tone as [Mr Darling]_n158 [himself]_p438 may have used on the real occasion. [Wendy]_n159 had danced with joy, just as the real [Mrs Darling]_n160 must have done.

Then [John]_n161 was born, with the extra pomp that [he]_p439 conceived due to the birth of a male, and [Michael]_n162 came from [his]_p440 bath to ask to be born also, but [John]_n163 said brutally that [they]_p441 did not want any more. [Michael]_n164 had nearly cried. "Nobody wants me,". [he]_p442 said, and of course the [lady]_n165 in the evening-dress could not stand that. "[I]_p443 do,". [she]_p444 said,. "[I]_p445 so want a third child. "[Boy]_n166 or girl?". asked [Michael]_n167 , not too hopefully. "[Boy]_n168.

Then [he]_p446 had leapt into [her]_p447 arms. Such a little thing for Mr and [Mrs Darling]_n169 and [Nana]_n170 to recall now, but not so little if that was to be [Michael]_n171 's last night in the nursery. [They]_p448 go on with [their]_p449 recollections. "[It]_p450 was then that [I]_p451 rushed in like a tornado, wasn't it?". [Mr Darling]_n172 would say, scorning [himself]_p452 and indeed [he]_p453 had been like a tornado. Perhaps there was some excuse for him. He, too, had been dressing for the party, and all had gone well with [him]_p454 until [he]_p455 came to [his]_p456 tie. [It]_p457 is an astounding thing to have to tell, but this man, though [he]_p458 knew about stocks and shares, had no real mastery of [his]_p459 tie. Sometimes the thing yielded to [him]_p460 without a contest, but there were occasions when [it]_p461 would have been better for the house if [he]_p462 had swallowed [his]_p463 pride and used a made-up tie. This was such an occasion.

[He]_p464 came rushing into the nursery with the crumpled little brute of a tie in [his]_p465 hand. "Why, what is the matter, father dear?. "Matter!". [he]_p466 yelled [he]_p467 really yelled. "This tie, [it]_p468 will not tie. ". [He]_p469 became dangerously sarcastic. "Not round [my]_p470 neck! Round the bed-post!
